The purpose of this chapter is to familiarize the reader
with guardianship through a summary of guardianship law.
Since guardianship is statutory, there is no substitute for a
review of applicable state law. However, statutes are not
always grouped together in one section or volume and por -
tions of the law may be left to local rules or customs. An
overview of the general law will assist in understanding
A national review of guardianship cannot provide answers
to specific disputed issues among parties in one state, nor
can it cover every possible issue that might be litigated. This
discussion provides the juvenile and family law practitioner
with a basic understanding in order that the statutes of his
or her state can be read more meaningfully and with an
Cases presented involve minors, even though adult
incompetency guardianship cases might be applicable. Ap -
pellate review is confined to issues of appointment, removal
of guardian and settlements on account.
may be used to hear and determine whether the appoint -
ment of a guardian is necessary, it is the court that decides
who will be appointed as guardian.

Some alternatives to guardianship are discussed,

lar case. Related issues are addressed in other chapters on
the chapter were collected from various state statutes as a
guide, and may need to be altered for individual use.
Guardian appointed in a state other
than the state of original appointment and who is subservi -
ent and assistive to the original guardian.
courts; other courts reserve the term to relate only to guard -
ian of the property. A state may use the term guardian refer -
ring to minors and conservator applying to adults.
French civil law term for guardian appointed to
control minor's property. Has other meanings in other
Guardian appointed by the state of
Adult status obtained in some states prior
to age of majority by marriage, court decree or military
granted in another state. Outside the original appointment
jurisdiction the guardian is considered a foreign guardian.
The foreign guardian must be assisted by a local guardian.
